What is the form realm?
If a dharma is form, it is called the form realm.
What is not the form realm?
The dharmas that are not form are called the formless realm.
What is the visible realm?
The form sense base is called the visible realm.
What is the invisible realm?
Except for the form sense base, the other dharmas are called the invisible realm.
What is the resistant realm?
The ten form sense bases are called the resistant realm.
What is the non-resistant realm?
The mind sense base and the dharma sense base are called the non-resistant realm.
What is the noble realm?
The dharmas that are without outflows are called the noble realm.
What is the non-noble realm?
The dharmas that have outflows are called the non-noble realm.
What is the realm with outflows?
The dharmas that have craving are called the realm with outflows.
What is the realm without outflows?
The dharmas that are without craving are called the realm without outflows.
What is the realm with craving?
The dharmas that have seeking are called the realm with craving.
What is the realm without craving?
If a dharma is not sought after, it is called the realm without craving.
What is the realm with seeking?
If a dharma is to be grasped, it is called the realm with seeking.
What is the realm without seeking?
If a dharma is not to be grasped, it is called the realm without seeking.
What is the realm of grasping?
If a dharma is grasped, it is called the realm of grasping.
What is the realm of non-grasping?
If a dharma is not grasped, it is called the realm of non-grasping.
What is the realm with grasping?
If a dharma is superior, it is called the realm with grasping.
What is the realm without grasping?
If a dharma is not superior, it is called the realm without grasping.
What is the realm with superiority?
If a dharma is grasped, it is called the realm with superiority.
What is the realm without superiority?
If a dharma is not grasped, it is called the realm without superiority.
What is the realm with superiority?
If a dharma realm is surpassed by another realm that is more excellent, it is called the realm with superiority.
What is the realm without superiority?
If a dharma realm is unsurpassed by any other realm, it is called the realm without surpass.
What is the realm of feeling?
If a dharma is internal, it is called the realm of feeling.
What is the realm of non-feeling?
If a dharma is external, it is called the realm of non-feeling.
What is the internal realm?
If a dharma is feeling, it is called the internal realm.
What is the external realm?
If a dharma is not feeling, it is called the external realm.
What is the realm with retribution?
If a dharma is a dharma with retribution, it is called the realm with retribution.
What is the realm without retribution?
If a dharma is either with retribution or neither with retribution nor a dharma with retribution, it is called the realm without retribution.
What is the mind realm?
The mental faculty is called the mind realm.
What is the non-mind realm?
Except for the mental faculty, the other dharmas are called the non-mind realm.
What is the realm associated with the mind?
If a dharma is mental, it is called the realm associated with the mind.
What is the realm not associated with the mind?
If a dharma is not a mental factor, it is called a non-associated compositional factor element.
What is a mental factor element?
Excluding the mind, the remaining conditioned dharmas are called a mental factor element.
What is a non-mental factor element?
If a dharma is not a conditioned dharma or the mind, it is called a non-mental factor element.
What is an object element?
If a dharma takes on characteristics and is the mind, it is called an object element.
What is a non-object element?
Excluding the mind, the remaining non-mental factor dharmas are called a non-object element.
What is an element associated with the mind?
If a dharma accompanies the mind, arises together with the mind, abides together with the mind, and ceases together with the mind, it is called an element associated with the mind.
What is an element not associated with the mind?

If a dharma does not accompany the mind, does not arise together with the mind, does not abide together with the mind, and does not cease together with the mind, it is called an element not associated with the mind.
What is an element that accompanies the mind?
If a dharma arises together with the mind, abides together with the mind, and ceases together with the mind, it is called an element that accompanies the mind.
What is an element that does not accompany the mind?
If a dharma does not arise together with the mind, does not abide together with the mind, and does not cease together with the mind, it is called a realm that does not follow the mind.
What is the realm of karma?
Bodily action, verbal action, and mental action are called the realm of karma.
What is not the realm of karma?
Except for bodily action, verbal action, and mental action, the other dharmas are called not the realm of karma.
What is the realm of karmic retribution?
If a dharma is loved or has a good retribution, it is called the realm of karmic retribution.
What is not the realm of karmic retribution?
If a dharma is retribution or neither retribution nor a dharma of retribution, it is called not the realm of karmic retribution.
What is the realm associated with karma?
If a dharma is associated with volition, it is called the realm associated with karma.
What is not the realm associated with karma?
If a dharma is not associated with volition, it is called not the realm associated with karma.
What is the realm that is neither associated with karma nor not associated with karma?
Volition is called the realm that is neither associated with karma nor not associated with karma.
What is the realm of the common karma?
If a dharma follows karma, arises together with karma, abides together with karma, and ceases together with karma, it is called the shared karmic realm.
What is the unshared karmic realm?
If a dharma does not follow karma, does not arise together with karma, does not abide together with karma, and does not cease together with karma, it is called the unshared karmic realm.
What is the realm that follows karma?
If a dharma arises together with karma, abides together with karma, and ceases together with karma, it is called the realm that follows karma.
What is the realm that does not follow karma?
If a dharma does not arise together with karma, does not abide together with karma, and does not cease together with karma, it is called the realm that does not follow karma.
What is the causal realm?

If a dharma is a condition, or if a dharma is not a condition but has retribution, or if a dharma is not a condition but has the retribution of good and the four great elements except for the attainment of fruition, it is called the causal realm.
What is the non-causal realm?
If a dharma is not a condition, has no retribution, and does not have the attainment of fruition that is not shared with karma, it is called the non-causal realm.
What is the realm with causes?
If a dharma has a thread, it is called the realm with causes.
What is the realm without cause?
If a dharma is without beginning, it is called the realm without cause.
What is the realm with beginning?
If a dharma has conditions, it is called the realm with beginning.
What is the realm without beginning?
If a dharma is without conditions, it is called the realm without beginning.
What is the realm with conditions?
If a dharma is conditioned, it is called the realm with conditions.
What is the realm without conditions?
If a dharma is unconditioned, it is called the realm without conditions.
What is the conditioned realm?
If a dharma has conditions, it is called the conditioned realm.
What is the unconditioned realm?
If a dharma is without conditions, it is called the unconditioned realm.
What is the realm of knowledge?
The knowledge of all dharmas as they are, the knowledge of seeing, is called the realm of knowledge.
What is the realm of non-knowledge?
There is no realm of non-knowledge.
Furthermore, it is said that all dharmas are not known as they are, the knowledge of seeing, is called the realm of non-knowledge.
What is the realm of consciousness?
All dharmas are cognized by consciousness and mental consciousness as objects, this is called the realm of consciousness.
What is the non-realm of consciousness?
There is no non-realm of consciousness.
Furthermore, it is said that all dharmas are not cognized by consciousness and mental consciousness as objects, this is called the non-realm of consciousness.
What is the realm of understanding?
All dharmas are understood as objects, this is called the realm of understanding.
What is the non-realm of understanding?
There is no non-realm of understanding.
Furthermore, it is said that all dharmas are not understood as objects, this is called the non-realm of understanding.
What is the realm of realization?
All dharmas are realized as objects, this is called the realm of realization.
What is the non-realm of realization?
There is no non-realm of realization.
Furthermore, it is said that all dharmas are not realized as objects, this is called the non-realm of realization.
What is the realm known by the knowledge of elimination?
If a dharma is unwholesome, it is called the realm known by the knowledge of elimination.
What is the realm not known by the knowledge of elimination?
If a dharma is wholesome or indeterminate, it is called the realm not known through the knowledge of elimination.
What is the realm of elimination?
If a dharma is unwholesome, it is called the realm of elimination.
What is the realm not to be eliminated?
If a dharma is wholesome or indeterminate, it is called the realm not to be eliminated.
What is the realm of cultivation?
If a dharma is wholesome, it is called the realm of cultivation.
What is the realm not to be cultivated?
If a dharma is unwholesome or indeterminate, it is called the realm not to be cultivated.
What is the realm of realization?
The realization of all dharmas as they are, known, seen, and understood, is called the realm of realization.
What is the realm not to be realized?
There is no realm not to be realized.
Moreover, it is said that all dharmas not realized as they are, known, seen, and understood, are called the realm not to be realized.
What is the realm of nirvana with remainder?
As the World-Honored One said:
What are those two realms of nirvana?
What are the two?
The realm of nirvana with remainder and the realm of nirvana without remainder.
What is nirvana with remainder?
It means this bhiká¹£u is an arhat, with all defilements exhausted, having accomplished what was to be done, laid down the heavy burden, attained his own goal,

and exhausted all afflictions with right knowledge. He has attained liberation from the aggregates, realms, and sense bases. He abides due to the causes and conditions of past karma, and experiences various sufferings and pleasures with his mind, having favorable and unfavorable [experiences]. This is called the realm of nirvana with a remainder.
What is the realm of nirvana without remainder?
It means when the bhiká¹£u's five aggregates cease, the future five aggregates will not continue to arise. This is called the realm of nirvana without remainder.
What is the wholesome realm?
If a dharma is cultivated, it is called the wholesome realm.
What is the unwholesome realm?
If a dharma is cut off, it is called the unwholesome realm.
What is the indeterminate realm?
If a dharma is experienced, or if a dharma is neither a ripening nor a ripening dharma, it is called the indeterminate realm.
What is the realm of training?
If a dharma is noble but not beyond training, it is called the realm of training.
What is the realm beyond training?
If a dharma is noble but not a learner's, it is called the realm of the non-learner.
What is the realm of neither learner nor non-learner?
If a dharma is not noble, it is called the realm of neither learner nor non-learner.
What is the realm of retribution?
If a dharma is experienced or has a good retribution, it is called the realm of retribution.
What is the realm of dharmas with retribution?
If a dharma has retribution, it is called the realm of dharmas with retribution.
What is the realm of neither retribution nor dharmas with retribution?
If a dharma is indeterminate and not included in my portion, it is called the realm of neither retribution nor dharmas with retribution.
What is the realm of that which is to be eliminated by seeing?
If a dharma is unwholesome but not to be eliminated by cultivation, it is called the realm of that which is to be eliminated by seeing.
What is the realm of that which is to be eliminated by cultivation?
If a dharma is unwholesome but not to be eliminated by seeing, it is called the realm of that which is to be eliminated by cultivation.
What is the realm of that which is neither to be eliminated by seeing nor by cultivation?
If a dharma is wholesome or indeterminate, it is called the realm of that which is neither to be eliminated by seeing nor by cultivation.
What is the realm of the cause of that which is to be eliminated by seeing?
If a dharma is seen to be eliminated, its retribution is called the realm of seen elimination.
What is the realm of thought elimination?
If a dharma is thought to be eliminated, or if a dharma is the retribution of a dharma that is thought to be eliminated, this is called the realm of thought elimination.
What is the realm of neither seen nor thought elimination?

If a dharma is wholesome, or if a dharma is the retribution of a wholesome dharma, or if a dharma is neither retribution nor the dharma of retribution, this is called the realm of neither seen nor thought elimination.
What is the realm of the lowly?
If a dharma is unwholesome, this is called the realm of the lowly.
What is the realm of the middling?
If a dharma is indeterminate, this is called the realm of the middling.
What is the realm of the superior?
If a dharma is wholesome, this is called the realm of the superior.
What is the realm of the lowly?
If a dharma is unwholesome or indeterminate, this is called the realm of the lowly.
What is the realm of the middling?
If a dharma is not the wholesome of the noble ones, this is called the realm of the middling.
What is the realm of the superior?
If a dharma is the pure of the noble ones, this is called the realm of the superior.
What is the coarse realm?
If a dharma is bound to the desire realm or the form realm, it is called the coarse realm.
What is the subtle realm?
If a dharma is bound to the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, or is unbound, it is called the subtle realm.
What is the minute realm?
If a dharma is bound to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, it is called the minute realm.

Furthermore, the coarse realm refers to dharmas bound to the desire realm, the form realm, the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, or the sphere of nothingness. This is called the coarse realm.
Furthermore, the subtle realm refers to dharmas that are unbound. This is called the subtle realm.
What is the minute realm?
If a dharma is bound to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, it is called the minute realm.
What is the realm of exertion?
If one exerts oneself, generates, arises, touches, and realizes, this is called the realm of exertion.
What is the realm of emergence?
If one exerts oneself widely and has not yet crossed over, this is called the realm of emergence.
What is the realm of crossing over?
If one advances and has already crossed the wide [river], this is called crossing the boundary.
What is the boundary of diligence?
The boundary of diligent effort is called the boundary of diligence.
What is the boundary of upholding?
The boundary of upholding the dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s is called the boundary of upholding.
What is the boundary of transcendence?
Transcending the boundary of transcendence is called the boundary of transcendence.
Furthermore, the boundary of diligence refers to diligent effort.
What is diligence?
If one's body and mind give rise to transcendence, and one's mind does not retreat but diligently exerts effort and advances correctly, this is called the boundary of diligence.
Furthermore, the boundary of upholding refers to mindfulness.
What is mindfulness?
Upholding the Dharma as one has heard and practiced, correctly upholding and abiding in the Dharma, not forgetting the thoughts and continuously mindful, this is called the boundary of upholding.
Furthermore, the boundary of transcendence refers to abandoning all afflictions, extinguishing craving, and attaining nirvÄá¹‡a, this is called the boundary of transcendence.
What is the boundary of severing?

If a bhiká¹£u contemplates the body in this way between trees or in an open space, seeing the evil consequences of evil actions in this world and the next, he abandons evil bodily actions and cultivates good bodily actions;

In this way, he contemplates the evil consequences of evil verbal and mental actions in this world and the next, abandons evil verbal and mental actions, and cultivates good verbal and mental actions. This is called the realm of cessation.
What is the realm of detachment?
The exhaustion of craving, detachment, and nirvÄá¹‡a are called the realm of detachment.
What is the realm of cessation?
The exhaustion of craving, cessation, and nirvÄá¹‡a are called the realm of cessation.
What is the desire realm?
From the AvÄ«ci great hell up to the Paranirmita-vaÅ›avartin heaven, the aggregates of form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are called the desire realm.
What is the form realm?
From the BrahmÄ heaven up to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven, the aggregates of form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are called the form realm.
What is the formless realm?

From the heavens of the sphere of infinite space up to the heavens of neither perception nor non-perception, if there are the aggregates of feeling, perception, formation, and consciousness, this is called the formless realm.
What is the form realm?
If a dharma is form, it is called the form realm.
What is not the form realm?
Except for the two cessations, the other non-form dharmas are called the non-form realm.
What is the cessation realm?
The two cessations, cessation through discernment and cessation not through discernment, are called the cessation realm.
What are the three realms of emergence?
As the World-Honored One said:
There are three realms of emergence.
What are the three realms of emergence?
They are emerging from desire and reaching form, emerging from form and reaching the formless, and emerging from the conditioned and reaching the unconditioned.
If what is done and accumulated ceases, this is called emergence.
What is meant by emerging from desire and reaching form?
If there is defiled heat born from conditions in desire, it does not exist in form. This is called emerging from desire and reaching form.
What is meant by emerging from form and reaching the formless?
If the burning of defilements arises from form, it does not exist in the formless realm. This is called emerging from form to the formless realm.
What is meant by the cessation of what is done and accumulated?
If the burning of defilements arises from formations, it does not exist in nirvana. This is called the cessation of what is done and accumulated.
This is called emerging.
These are called the three realms of emergence.
What is the past realm?
If a dharma has already arisen and ceased, it is called the past realm.
What is the future realm?
If a dharma has not yet arisen or emerged, it is called the future realm.
What is the present realm?
If a dharma has not yet ceased, it is called the present realm.
What is the realm that is neither past, future, nor present?
If a dharma is unconditioned, it is called the realm that is neither past, future, nor present.
What is the past object realm?
Contemplating the past, if a dharma has arisen, it is called the past object realm.
What is the future object realm?
Contemplating future dharmas that have not yet arisen is called the future object realm.
What is the present object realm?
Contemplating present dharmas that have already arisen is called the present object realm.
What is the non-past, non-future, non-present object realm?
Contemplating dharmas that are neither past, future, nor present, that have already arisen, is called the non-past, non-future, non-present object realm.
What is the realm bound to the desire realm?
Dharmas that are defiled by the outflows of desire are called the realm bound to the desire realm.
What is the realm bound to the form realm?
Dharmas that are defiled by the outflows of form are called the realm bound to the form realm.
What is the realm bound to the formless realm?
Dharmas that are defiled by the outflows of the formless realm are called the realm bound to the formless realm.
What is the unattached realm?
Dharmas that are holy and undefiled realms are called the unattached realm.
What is the form realm?
The form aggregate, this is called the form realm.
What is the feeling realm?
The feeling aggregate, this is called the feeling realm.
What is the perception realm?
The perception aggregate, this is called the perception realm.
What is the formation realm?
The formation aggregate, this is called the formation realm.
What is the consciousness realm?
The consciousness aggregate, this is called the consciousness realm.
What are the five realms of emergence?
As the World-Honored One said, there are five realms of emergence.
What are the five?
It is said that when a bhiká¹£u thinks of desire, his mind does not incline towards desire, is not clear, does not abide, and does not understand;

thinking of emergence, the mind emerges, the mind inclines towards clarity, abides, and understands, the mind is well-reached, well-tamed, and well-cultivated. If the mind emerges and understands in relation to desire, the burning defilements arising from desire emerge and are understood, and he does not experience such feelings. This is called emerging from the desire realm.
Furthermore, when a bhiká¹£u thinks of ill-will, his mind does not incline towards ill-will, is not clear, does not abide, and does not understand;

When one is mindful and not angry, the mind does not become angry or hostile, and the mind turns towards pure abiding and understanding. The mind is well-directed, well-tamed, and well-cultivated. If the mind arises with understanding and insight regarding anger, the defilements and mental afflictions born from anger are eliminated, and one does not experience that pain. This is called the realm of transcending anger.
Furthermore, when a bhiká¹£u is mindful of harm, when he is mindful of harm, the mind does not turn towards harm, is not clear, does not abide, and does not understand.

When one is mindful of non-harm, the mind turns towards non-harm, pure abiding and understanding. The mind is well-directed, well-tamed, and well-cultivated. If the mind arises with understanding and insight regarding harm, the defilements and mental afflictions born from harm are eliminated, and one does not experience that pain. This is called the realm of transcending harm.
Furthermore, when a bhiká¹£u is mindful of form, the mind does not turn towards form, is not clear, does not abide, and does not understand.

When one is mindful of formlessness, the mind turns towards formlessness, pure abiding and understanding. The mind is well-directed, well-tamed, and well-cultivated. If the mind arises with understanding and insight regarding form, the defilements and mental afflictions born from form are eliminated, and one does not experience that pain. This is called the realm of transcending form.
Furthermore, a bhiká¹£u contemplates his own body, but his mind does not incline towards his own body, is not clear, does not abide, and does not understand;

Contemplating the cessation of his own body, the mind towards the cessation of his own body inclines towards clarity, abiding and understanding. The mind well reaches, well adjusts, and well cultivates. If the mind gives rise to understanding and arises regarding one's own body, the burning defilements born from conditions of one's own body give rise to understanding and separation. One does not receive this pain. This is called exiting one's own body realm.
These are called the five realms of exit.
What are the six realms of exit?
As the World-Honored One said, the six realms of exit.
As a bhiká¹£u speaks to another bhiká¹£u like this:
Bhiká¹£u!
I closely cultivate the practice of a mind of loving-kindness, making it my vehicle and possession, being careful, aware, and well-advancing. I am covered by a mind of ill-will.
That bhiká¹£u reproaches this bhiká¹£u:
Bhiká¹£u!
Do not speak like this, do not slander the World-Honored One.
Slandering the World-Honored One is not good, the World-Honored One does not speak like this.
Bhiká¹£u!
This is not a place of hope.

If one cultivates the mind of loving-kindness, becomes intimate with it, and practices it a lot, if one makes it a vehicle and makes it a possession, if one is careful, mindful, and makes good progress, then it is impossible for the mind to be covered by anger.
The World-Honored One said:
Monks!
If you cultivate the mind of loving-kindness, become intimate with it, and practice it a lot, then it is impossible for the mind to be covered by anger.
Furthermore, a monk may say to another monk:
Monks!

I cultivate the mind of compassion, become intimate with it, and practice it a lot, making it a vehicle and a possession, being careful, mindful, and making good progress, yet I am still covered by a harmful mind.
That monk should admonish this monk:
Monks!
Do not speak like this, do not slander the World-Honored One.
Slandering the World-Honored One is not good, the World-Honored One would not say it like that.
Monks!
This is not a place of hope.ğŸ”½Monks!

If one's mind of compassion and understanding is cultivated and practiced much, if one has made it a vehicle and a possession, if one is careful, mindful, and well-advanced, it is impossible for one whose mind is covered by the thought of harm.
The World-Honored One said:
Monks!
If one has a mind of harm, if one has a mind of compassion and understanding, if one cultivates and practices much, it is immeasurable.
Moreover, monks, if a monk speaks to another monk like this:
I cultivate and practice much with a mind of joy and understanding, I have made it a vehicle and a possession, I am careful, mindful, and well-advanced, but I am still covered by an unhappy mind.
That monk should admonish this monk:
Monks!

What is the earth element?
There are two kinds of earth elements: internal earth elements and external earth elements.
What are the internal earth elements?

If in this body there is what is received as solid, bones, teeth, hair, body hair, skin, flesh, muscles, veins, spleen, kidneys, liver, lungs, heart, stomach, large intestine, small intestine, large belly, small belly, this body and the rest that receive what is solid inside, this is called the internal earth element.
What are the external earth elements?

If externally there is what is not received as solid, copper, iron, lead, tin, white copper, gold, silver, pearls, lapis lazuli, shells, agate, coral, coins, precious shells, sand, stones, grass, trees, branches, leaves, stems, joints, and the rest of what is externally not received as solid, this is called the external earth element.
Thus, the internal earth element and the external earth element are called the earth element.
What is the water element?
There are two kinds of water elements: internal water elements and external water elements.
What are the internal water elements?

If water is received inside this body, such as saliva, bile, sweat, fat, marrow, brain, grease, tears, mucus, pus, blood, urine, and other water received inside this body, this is called the internal water element.
What is the external water element?

If the external water element is not received, such as ghee, oil, honey, molasses, black sesame oil, milk, curd, whey, liquor, sugarcane wine, honey wine, and other external water that is not received, this is called the external water element.
Thus, the internal and external water elements are called the water element.
What is the fire element?
There are two fire elements, the internal fire element and the external fire element.
What is the internal fire element?

If fire is received inside this body, heat or that which can cause heat, heat the body, burn inside, or digest food and drink, and other fire received inside this body, this is called the internal fire element.
What is the external fire element?

If external fire is not experienced as heat, if fire is hot, the sun is hot, jewels are hot, houses are hot, walls are hot, mountains are hot, grain vapor is hot, grass is hot, wood is hot, cow dung is hot, and other external fires are hot but not experienced, this is called the external fire element.
Thus, the internal fire element and the external fire element are called the fire element.
What is the wind element?
There are two kinds of wind elements: the internal wind element and the external wind element.
What is the internal wind element?

If it is a wind that is experienced internally in this body, upward wind, downward wind, wind that supports the joints, wind that causes lameness and paralysis, wind that moves through the bones and joints, wind of exhalation and inhalation, and other internal winds that are experienced, this is called the internal wind element.
What is the external wind element?

If it is an external wind that is not experienced, if it is an east wind, a west wind, a north wind, a south wind, a dusty wind, a dustless wind, a cold wind, a hot wind, a black wind, a whirlwind that moves the earth, and other external winds that are not experienced, this is called the external wind element.
Such internal wind and external wind are called the wind element.
What is the space element?
There are two kinds of space elements: internal space element and external space element.
What is the internal space element?

If there is space within the body that is not covered by the four great elements, such as the ear, nose, mouth, the place where food and drink enter, the place where food and drink stay, the place where food and drink exit, and other spaces within the body that are not covered by the four great elements, this is called the internal space element.
What is the external space element?

If there is external space that is not perceived and not covered by the four great elements, such as a pit, a well, a jar, a pot, a valley, and other external spaces that are not perceived and not covered by the four great elements, this is called the external space element.
Such internal space element and external space element are called the space element.
What is the consciousness element?
The six groups of consciousness: eye-consciousness, ear-, nose-, tongue-, body-, and mind-consciousness - this is called the consciousness element.
What is the pleasant element?
The pleasant feeling from eye contact, ear, nose, tongue, and body contact, and the faculty of pleasure, are called the pleasant element.
What is the painful element?
The painful feeling from eye contact, ear, nose, tongue, and body contact, and the faculty of pain, are called the painful element.
What is the joyful element?
If the mind experiences pleasant feeling and the faculty of joy, it is called the joyful element.
What is the sorrowful element?
If the mind experiences painful feeling and the faculty of sorrow, it is called the sorrowful element.
What is the neutral element?

The feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant in body and mind, namely, the feeling that is neither painful nor pleasant from eye contact, ear, nose, tongue, and body contact, and the faculty of equanimity, is called the neutral element.
What is the ignorance element?
The unwholesome root of delusion is called the ignorance element.
What is the desire element?
Desire for the desire realm is called the desire element.
What is the ill-will element?
Ill-will towards the ill-will realm is called the ill-will element.
What is the harmfulness element?
Harmfulness towards the harmfulness realm is called the harmfulness element.
What is the desire realm?
If there is desire, lust, attachment, love, joy, dependence, fixation, thirst, burning, and entrapment in desire, this is called the desire realm.
What is the anger realm?
If one deceives and harms sentient beings, hoping to oppress and cut off their life roots, this is called the anger realm.
What is the harm realm?
If one deceives and harms sentient beings, hoping to oppress and cut off their life roots, this is called the harm realm.
What is the desire realm?

The five desires are love, joy, satisfaction, and desire for attractive forms. The continuity of desire and defilement is the continuity of eye consciousness, form, love, joy, satisfaction, and desire for attractive forms. The continuity of desire and defilement is the continuity of ear, nose, tongue, and body consciousness, contact, love, joy, satisfaction, and desire for attractive forms. If others desire others' territories, others' wives, or others' possessions, and wish for me to obtain them, if one is greedy, very greedy, ultimately greedy, and associated with longing, love, desire, heavy desire, ultimate desire, and other desirable dharmas, if one is greedy, very greedy, ultimately greedy, longing, loving, desiring, heavily desiring, ultimately desiring, this is called the desire realm.
What is the realm of hatred?

If one harms many sentient beings or few sentient beings, binds them, and causes them to suffer in various ways, if one is angry, very angry, ultimately angry, associated with anger, hatred, aversion, a troubled mind, stubbornness, lack of kindness, lack of compassion, and lack of benefit, this is called the realm of hatred.
What is the realm of harm?

If one harms sentient beings with fists, tiles, stones, knives, weapons, or other means of harm, deceives and injures sentient beings, and invades and disturbs with the hope of ending their lives, this is called the realm of harm.
What is the realm of escape?
Excluding kindness and compassion, the rest of the wholesome dharmas that lead to liberation are called the realm of escape.
What is the realm of non-anger?
Kindness is called the realm of non-anger.
What is the realm of non-harming?
Compassion is called the realm of non-harming.
What is the realm of light?
The light of form and the light of wisdom.
What is the light of form?

The light of fire, the light of the sun, the light of the moon, the light of jewels, the light of stars, the light of the Buddha, the light of sentient beings, and other lights created by the four elements that illuminate - this is called the light of form.
What is the light of wisdom?
The three kinds of wisdom: the wisdom of contemplation, the wisdom of hearing, and the wisdom of cultivation - this is called the light of wisdom.
Such lights of form and wisdom are called the realm of light.
What is the realm of purity?
The pure liberation and other pure forms that can purify forms, which one never tires of seeing, are called the pure realm.
What is the form realm?
The form sense base and the form aggregate are called the form realm.
What is the sphere of the base of infinite space?
The sphere of the base of infinite space is either the conditioned sphere of the base of infinite space or the unconditioned sphere of the base of infinite space.
What is the conditioned sphere of the base of infinite space?
The concentration of the base of infinite space and the birth in the base of infinite space.
What is the concentration of the base of infinite space?
If a bhiká¹£u, having abandoned all perceptions of form, put an end to perceptions of resistance, and not paying attention to perceptions of diversity, accomplishes the sphere of infinite space,
What is the birth in the base of infinite space?

Because of being close to this concentration and practicing it a lot, the four kinds of self-identifications in the gods of the base of infinite space, which are the perceptions, volitions, and consciousnesses, are called the birth in the base of infinite space.
Thus, the concentration of the base of infinite space and the birth in the base of infinite space are called the conditioned sphere of the base of infinite space.
What is the unconditioned sphere of the base of infinite space?
If it is eliminated by wisdom, the sphere of infinite space is eliminated, which is called the sphere of infinite space.
The same applies to the sphere of nothingness and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
What are the eighteen elements?

The eye element, form element, eye-consciousness element, ear element, sound element, ear-consciousness element, nose element, smell element, nose-consciousness element, tongue element, taste element, tongue-consciousness element, body element, tactile element, body-consciousness element, mind element, dharma element, mind-consciousness element - these are called the eighteen elements.

What is intentional action?
Mental action is called intentional action.
What is action after having intended?
Bodily action and verbal action are called action after having intended.
Why is it called action?
If an action is intentionally done and one experiences retribution, it is called intentional action.
What is unintentional action?
If an action is not done and one does not experience retribution, it is called unintentional action.
What is accepted action?
If an action has retribution, it is called accepted action.
What is non-accepted action?
If an action has no retribution, it is called non-accepted action.
Furthermore, accepted action refers to an action that has retribution and has the intention of retribution, it is called accepted action.
Furthermore, non-accepted action refers to an action that has no retribution, bodily action and verbal action, it is called non-accepted action.
What is action with little to be experienced?
If an action experiences little retribution, it is called action with little to be experienced.
What is action with much to be experienced?
If an action does not experience little retribution, it is called action with much to be experienced.
What is matured action?
If an action is experienced soon, it is called matured action.
What is non-matured action?
If an action is not experienced soon, it is called non-matured action.
What is form-based karma?
Bodily karma and verbal karma are called form-based karma.
What is non-form-based karma?
Mental karma is called non-form-based karma.
What is visible karma?
If karma is included in the form aggregate, it is called visible karma.
What is invisible karma?
If karma is included in the dharma aggregate, it is called invisible karma.
What is resistant karma?
If karma is included in the sound aggregate or the form aggregate, it is called resistant karma.
What is non-resistant karma?
If karma is included in the dharma aggregate, it is called non-resistant karma.
What is noble karma?
If karma is uncontaminated, it is called noble karma.
What is non-noble karma?
If karma is contaminated, it is called non-noble karma.
What is contaminated karma?
If karma has craving, it is called contaminated karma.
What is uncontaminated karma?
If karma is without craving, it is called uncontaminated karma.
What is karma with craving?
If an action has craving, it is called an action of craving.
What is an action without craving?
If an action is without craving, it is called an action without craving.
What is an action with seeking?
If an action is to be taken up, it is called an action with seeking.
What is an action without seeking?
If an action is not to be taken up, it is called an action without seeking.
What is an action to be taken up?
If an action has grasping, it is called an action to be taken up.
What is an action not to be taken up?
If an action is without grasping, it is called an action not to be taken up.
What is an action with grasping?
If an action has superiority, it is called an action with grasping.
What is an action without grasping?
If an action is without superiority, it is called an action without grasping.
What is an action with superiority?
If an action has grasping, it is called an action with superiority.
What is an action without superiority?
If an action is without grasping, it is called an action without superiority.
Furthermore, there is superior karma. If this karma has other karma that surpasses it in excellence, it is called karma with superior karma.
Furthermore, there is non-superior karma. If this karma has no other karma that surpasses it in excellence, it is called karma without superior karma.
What is karma that is experienced?
If karma is internal, it is called karma that is experienced.
What is karma that is not experienced?
If karma is external, it is called karma that is not experienced.
What is internal karma?
If karma is experienced, it is called internal karma.
What is external karma?
If karma is not experienced, it is called external karma.
What is karma with retribution?
If karma has retribution, it is called karma with retribution.
What is karma without retribution?
If karma is not retribution, it is called karma without retribution.
What is karma associated with the mind?
If karma is mental, it is called karma associated with the mind.
What is karma not associated with the mind?
If karma is not mental, it is called karma not associated with the mind.
What is mental activity?
If an action is a condition, it is called mental activity.
What is not mental activity?
If an action is not a condition, it is called not mental activity.
What is conditioned action?
If an action is mental, it is called conditioned action.
What is unconditioned action?
If an action is not mental, it is called unconditioned action.
What is action that accompanies the mind?
If an action follows the mind, arises together with the mind, abides together with the mind, and ceases together with the mind, it is called action that accompanies the mind.
What is action that does not accompany the mind?

If an action does not follow the mind, does not arise together with the mind, does not abide together with the mind, and does not cease together with the mind, it is called action that does not accompany the mind.
What is action that follows the mind?
If an action arises together with the mind, abides together with the mind, and ceases together with the mind, it is called action that follows the mind.
What is action that does not follow the mind?
If an action does not arise together with the mind, does not abide together with the mind, and does not cease together with the mind, it is called action that does not follow the mind.
What is the karma that is not associated with karma?
If karma is not associated with volition, it is called the karma that is not associated with karma.
What is the karma that is neither associated with karma nor not associated with karma?
Volition is called the karma that is neither associated with karma nor not associated with karma.
What is the karma that accompanies karma?
If karma follows karma, arises together with karma, abides together with karma, and ceases together with karma, it is called the karma that accompanies karma.
What is the karma that does not accompany karma?
If karma does not follow karma, does not arise together with karma, does not abide together with karma, and does not cease together with karma, it is called the karma that does not accompany karma.
What is the karma that is subject to change?
If karma arises together with karma, abides together with karma, and ceases together with karma, it is called the karma that is subject to change.
What is the karma that is not subject to change?
It does not arise together with karma, does not abide together with karma, and does not cease together with karma, it is called the karma that is not subject to change.
What is the karma that is a cause?
If karma is a condition for karma, or if karma is a good cause, it is called the karma that is a cause.
What is the karma that is not a cause?
If an action is not a condition and has no retribution, and the retribution is not shared by the action, it is called an action without cause.
What is an action with cause?
If an action has a beginning, it is called an action with cause.
What is an action with a beginning?
If an action has conditions and transforms the action, and the action is shared by the action, it is called an action with a beginning.
What is an action with conditions?
If an action is conditioned, it is called an action with conditions.
What is a conditioned action?
If an action has conditions, it is called a conditioned action.
How is an action known?
All actions are known as they are known, seen, and understood. This is called knowing an action.
What is an action that is not known?
There is no action that is not known.
Furthermore, it is said that all actions are not known as they are known, seen, and understood. This is called an action that is not known.
What is an action that is recognized?
All actions are recognized by consciousness, mental consciousness, and as they are recognized. This is called an action that is recognized.
What is an action that is not recognized?
There is no action that is not recognized.
Furthermore, it is said that all actions are not recognized by the consciousness or the mental consciousness as they are by the perceiving consciousness, and this is called non-cognized action.
What is understood action?
Understanding and seeing things as they are, this is called understood action.
What is non-understood action?
There is no non-understood action.
Furthermore, it is said that all actions are not understood as they are by things, and this is called non-understood action.
What is accomplished action?
All actions are accomplished as they are seen and known, and this is called accomplished action.
What is non-accomplished action?
There is no non-accomplished action.
What is action known by the knowledge of elimination?
If action is unwholesome, it is called action known by the knowledge of elimination.
What is action not known by the knowledge of elimination?
If action is wholesome or indeterminate, it is called action not known by the knowledge of elimination.
What is eliminated action?
If action is unwholesome, it is called eliminated action.
What is non-eliminated action?
If action is wholesome or indeterminate, it is called non-eliminated action.
What is cultivated action?
If an action is wholesome, it is called an action of cultivation.
What is an action of non-cultivation?
If an action is unwholesome or indeterminate, it is called an action of non-cultivation.
What is an action of realization?
All actions that are realized as they are known and seen, this is called an action of realization.
What is an action of non-realization?
There is no action of non-realization.
Furthermore, it is said that all actions that are not realized as they are known and seen, this is called an action of non-realization.
What is an action of teaching?
Bodily action and verbal action, this is called an action of teaching.
What is an action of non-teaching?
Mental action, this is called an action of non-teaching.
What is a bodily action of teaching?
If bodily action is included in the form aggregate, it is called a bodily action of teaching.
What is a bodily action of non-teaching?
If bodily action is included in the dharma aggregate, it is called a bodily action of non-teaching.
What is a verbal action of teaching?
If verbal action is included in the sound aggregate, it is called a verbal action of teaching.
What is a verbal action of non-teaching?
If it is included in the dharma element of speech, it is called non-manifest action of speech.
What is bodily action?
If an action is neither a condition nor an action of speech, it is called bodily action.
What is verbal action?
If an action is neither a condition nor bodily action, it is called verbal action.
What is mental action?
If an action is a condition, it is called mental action.
What is action of morality?

If an action is produced by a wholesome mind, and the bodily actions of going, coming, bending, stretching, and turning, the verbal actions of collecting sounds, phrases, and language, the non-manifest actions of morality of body and speech with outflows, right speech, right action, right livelihood, and wholesome volition, it is called action of morality.
What is action of immorality?

If an action is produced by an unwholesome mind, and the bodily actions of going, coming, bending, stretching, and turning, the verbal actions of collecting sounds, phrases, and language, the non-manifest actions of immorality of body and speech, and unwholesome volition, it is called action of immorality.
What is action that is neither morality nor immorality?

If the karma is indeterminate and arises from an indeterminate mind, and is the bodily action of going, coming, bending, stretching, turning, the verbal action of uttering sounds, phrases, and speech, and the indeterminate volition, this is called neither moral discipline nor its absence.
What is bodily moral discipline?

If the bodily action is wholesome, arises from a wholesome mind, and is the bodily action of going, coming, bending, stretching, turning, the bodily moral discipline that is the unmanifest form, right action, and right livelihood, this is called bodily moral discipline.
What is bodily immoral discipline?

Not killing, not stealing, not engaging in sexual misconduct, not speaking falsely, not engaging in divisive speech, not speaking harshly, not engaging in idle chatter, not being greedy, not harboring ill-will, and practicing right view - these are called the ten wholesome courses of action.
What are the ten dharmas that, when accomplished, lead to falling into hell as quickly as throwing a jujube leaf?
Killing, up to wrong view - these ten dharmas, when accomplished, lead to falling into hell as quickly as throwing a jujube leaf.
What are the ten dharmas that, when accomplished, lead to being reborn in a good place as quickly as throwing a jujube leaf?
Not killing, up to practicing right view - these ten, when accomplished, lead to being reborn in a good place as quickly as throwing a jujube leaf.
What are the twenty dharmas that, when accomplished, lead to falling into hell as quickly as throwing a jujube leaf?
Killing oneself, causing others to kill, up to wrong view, causing others to have wrong view - these twenty dharmas, when accomplished, lead to falling into hell as quickly as throwing a jujube leaf.
What are the twenty dharmas that, when accomplished, lead to being reborn in a good place as quickly as throwing a jujube leaf?

oneself not killing living beings, teaching others not to kill living beings, up to oneself practicing right view, teaching others to practice right view, these twenty dharmas accomplished, one is born in a good place as quickly as an arrow.

How are thirty dharmas accomplished, being born in a good place as quickly as an arrow?

oneself not killing living beings, teaching others not to kill living beings, praising not killing living beings, up to oneself practicing right view, teaching others right view, praising the practice of right view, these are called thirty dharmas accomplished, being born in a good place as quickly as an arrow.
How are forty dharmas accomplished, falling into hell as quickly as an arrow?
